awd_titl_txt: Tailoring of the Elastic Postbucking Response of Cylindrical Shells:  A Route for Exploiting Instabilities in Mechanical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Elastic instability, which refers to the sudden loss of compression load carrying capacity of a structural element, is traditionally considered a failure limit. Yet, unstable behavior involves a sudden change of the structure's geometry and the release of accumulated energy. Thus, a new way of thinking is emerging for using the unstable response of slender structures for purposes that seem to be rapidly increasing and diversifying. Cylindrical shells are among the structural elements most affected by instabilities (commonly seen as a negative trait) but their geometry provides unique opportunities for controlling their unstable response, which can display multiple unstable transitions in a recoverable manner. The research hypothesis is that cylindrical shells can be designed such that their unstable response is controlled through optimal geometric and material stiffness distributions on the shell surface. The research findings will create new possibilities for the development of materials and devices that use instabilities for applications such as sensing, actuation, control, energy harvesting, and energy dissipation; advances that in turn could also facilitate the development of novel smart, active and multifunctional materials and structures. The project will allow training of a Ph.D. student and educational and outreach components will broaden access to the project's core knowledge to undergraduate and high-school students.

The core research idea is that the features in the far elastic postbuckling response of cylindrical shells can be fully characterized, modified, and potentially tailored. The features of interest are not the initial elastic stiffness or the first bifurcation load, but a response with multiple stable to unstable transitions, the equilibrium path loading stiffnesses, the released kinetic energy at critical point transitions, and the dissipated energy during cyclic loading. Topology and shape optimization techniques will be expanded to achieve the desired response and experiments will validate computational designs and finite-element based simulations. Analysis and design frameworks will be developed for axially loaded cylinders with controllable elastic postbuckling behavior. The key innovation will be proving that the elastic postbuckling response of cylindrical shells can be tailored through the design of material and geometric features on the shell's surface, thus transforming a behavior traditionally seen as undesirable into an opportunity for use in smart materials and structures. The research will generate new knowledge on the extent and means to control and design the elastic postbuckling response of cylindrical shells, which will provide new concepts and guidance for the use of tailorable structural instabilities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Thin-walled cylindrical shells (cylinders) find wide uses as structural elements in various applications, from traditional civil works to aerospace structures. Yet, a strict constraint to their use is their susceptibility to buckling, an instability condition that leads to the loss of load-bearing capacity and thus considered a failure condition. Furthermore, buckling in thin-walled cylinders is highly susceptible to manufacturing imperfections, making buckling difficult to predict, and thus undependable and undesirable. However, an emergent field of research has shown that, if controlled, buckling, in particular elastic buckling, can be used as an asset to provide structures with adaptability and functionality. Cylindrical shells are well suited to take advantage of such response since their curvilinear geometry provides a natural restraint to the increase of transverse deformations from buckling, thus leading to responses featuring multiple elastic buckling events, or multiple elastic instabilities.

The aim of this research was to demonstrate that the elastic post-buckling response of cylindrical shells could be controlled and tailored, thus transforming a behavior traditionally seen as undesirable into an opportunity for use in smart materials and structures. The concept of Non-uniform Stiffness Distributed (NSD) cylindrical shells, achieved through strategic material and stiffness layout distributions on the shell surface, was proposed and studied. NSD shells provide desirable response features in the far post-buckling response regime and reduce the imperfection sensitivity of shells. The noted features are the number of critical stability transitions during elastic post-buckling response, the released kinetic energy during mode transitions, the spacing of the mode switching events, the branch loading stiffnesses, and the dissipated energy during cyclic loading.

The NSD concept uses discrete thickness variations along the cylinder?s wall such as to discretize the global behavior as a superposed response of individual panels. Leveraging the superposed response revealed key parameters that control the global behavior. The discrete shell surfaces are thus grouped into functional panels. The targeted local buckling events occur at the center of ?buckling panels,? while ?stiffener panels? serve as lateral boundary conditions to the buckling region. The buckling panels feature top and bottom regions that axially bound the buckling areas with thickness variations determining the critical strain at which local buckling occurs. By designing the individual buckling panel?s behavior such that they each experience a single snap-buckling instability, the global response consisting of multiple local buckling occurrences can thereby be controlled.

Numerical simulations were conducted using the finite element method to characterize the mechanical response of NSD cylinders; and prototyped cylinders were fabricated through 3D polymer printing to verify the numerical results and showcase the design concepts. Experimental and numerical results confirmed that the multiple local buckling occurrences in the elastic post-buckling regime of axially compressed cylindrical shells were predefined and controlled by the proposed design concept in terms of the local buckling locations, sequence, and critical strains.

An analytical framework was developed to predict the post-buckling response of NSD cylinders under uniform axial compression by assuming that the buckling events in the targeted areas were independent from each other. The model has three key elements: i) subdivision of the cylinder into parallel panels with linear and nonlinear response, ii) a semi-analytical approximate model to predict the nonlinear response of the cylindrical panels, and iii) integrating the response from the individual panels. The model was validated and shown to be accurate by comparing its predicted response for several NSD cylinders against results from experimental tests on 3D printed units and finite element analyses.

This research has demonstrated that the elastic post-buckling response of compressed cylinders can be controlled and accurately predicted by fully characterizing and understanding the effects of non-uniform material stiffness distributions in the attainment and control of post-buckling response in time (triggering of specific equilibrium trajectories) and space (buckling localization at predefined zones). The new knowledge can promote the use of such behavior by allowing the design of cylindrical shells with desirable post-buckling response for purposes of emerging interest, including actuation, sensing, control, energy harvesting and energy dissipation.

Outreach educational activities for K-12 students were developed and conducted biannually. The events consisted on lectures related to the history of structural engineering, concepts on materials and structures, concepts on structural design and then a hands-on activity on which they need to optimize the design of a bridge model and conduct a physical test. Knowledge generated from the project was disseminated through journal and conference publications, and technical presentations. The project allowed support and research training of a post-doctoral researcher and three Ph.D. students.


Last Modified: 09/14/2021
Modified by: Rigoberto Burgueno
